text: it may look like an ordinary bike but
this two wheeler has a secret weapon
installed on its rear hub is a new
device that stores up the energy
produced from pedal strokes and then
releases this if the cyclist needs a
push
it's been named the Copenhagen wheel in
honor of one of the world's most
bike-friendly cities the design is the
brainchild of two inventors at the
Massachusetts Institute of Technology
the wheel contains a computer batteries
and sensors that can determine when a
biker requires help it's easy to install
and allows bikes to travel up to 20
miles an hour if a rider gets tired over
the past few years we've seen cycling
Renaissance throughout the world people
are looking for alternatives the wheel
also uses wireless technology to sync up
with a cyclist smartphone and contract
things like the distance a person has
traveled or how many calories they've
burned so far more than 800 have been
sold worldwide and as more and more
people take up cycling reinventing the
wheel may prove to be a lucrative
business Claire Brennan BBC news
